# userActivity

**Instance Property**

An object encapsulating a user activity supported by this responder.

## Declaration

```swift
@MainActor var userActivity: NSUserActivity? { get set }
```

## Discussion

By setting the [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSResponder/userActivity] property on a responder, the [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Foundation/NSUserActivity] object becomes managed by AppKit. You should override [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSResponder/updateUserActivityState(_:)] to write lazily any state data representing the user’s activity to the `userInfo` dictionary. AppKit automatically saves user activities it manages at appropriate times. Multiple responders can share a single [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Foundation/NSUserActivity] instance, in which case they all get a callback, such as [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSResponder/updateUserActivityState(_:)], when the system updates the user activity object.



In macOS, [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Foundation/NSUserActivity] objects managed by [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSResponder] automatically [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Foundation/NSUserActivity/becomeCurrent()] based on the main window and the responder chain.

A responder object can set its [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSResponder/userActivity] property to `nil` if it no longer wants to participate. Any [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Foundation/NSUserActivity] objects that AppKit manages but have no associated responders (or documents) are automatically invalidated.

You can use this property from any thread, and it’s key-value observable (KVO).

## Supporting User Activities

- **updateUserActivityState(_:)**: Updates the state of the given user activity.
